questions.question: A 5.0 kg cart moves at a constant velocity of 4.0 m/s. What is its momentum?
questions.explanation: Momentum p = m × v = 5.0 kg × 4.0 m/s = 20 kg·m/s.

questions.question: A constant net force of 10 N acts on a 2.0 kg object for 5.0 seconds. What is the impulse delivered to the object?
questions.explanation: Impulse J = F × Δt = 10 N × 5.0 s = 50 N·s.

questions.question: A ball of mass 0.50 kg initially moving at 6.0 m/s is brought to rest by a constant force over 2.0 seconds. What is the change in momentum?
questions.explanation: Change in momentum Δp = m(v_f - v_i) = 0.50 kg × (0 - 6.0) m/s = -3.0 kg·m/s.

questions.question: A hockey puck (0.17 kg) experiences a change in momentum of 8.5 kg·m/s over 0.25 seconds. What average force acted on it?
questions.explanation: Average force F_avg = Δp / Δt = 8.5 kg·m/s / 0.25 s = 34 N.

questions.question: Two objects have the same kinetic energy. Object A has twice the mass of Object B. How does the magnitude of momentum of A compare to B?
questions.explanation: From KE = p²/(2m), equal KE and m_A = 2m_B gives p_A²/(4m_B) = p_B²/(2m_B) ⇒ p_A² = 2p_B² ⇒ p_A = √2 p_B.

questions.question: A 0.10 kg stone strikes a wall at 20 m/s perpendicularly and rebounds with 15 m/s. What is the magnitude of its change in momentum?
questions.explanation: Take toward wall as positive. Δp = m(v_f - v_i) = 0.10 kg × (-15 - 20) m/s = -3.5 kg·m/s. Magnitude is 3.5 kg·m/s.

questions.question: A 4.0 kg object initially at rest receives an impulse of 32 N·s. What is its final speed?
questions.explanation: Impulse = change in momentum. J = m v_f since initial p = 0. So v_f = J/m = 32 N·s / 4.0 kg = 8.0 m/s.

questions.question: A 1200 kg car traveling east at 10 m/s turns north and continues at 10 m/s. What is the magnitude of its change in momentum?
A truck and a car have the same momentum. If they are both stopped by the same constant braking force, which stops in a shorter distance?
questions.explanation: Stopping distance d = v²/(2a) = (p/m)² / (2F/m) = p²/(2mF). For same p and F, d ∝ 1/m. Larger mass (truck) has smaller d.

questions.question: A 0.20 kg ball hits a wall horizontally at 8.0 m/s and rebounds at 6.0 m/s at 30° from the wall. Impact lasts 0.04 s. What is the average force magnitude? (Consider only perpendicular momentum change.)

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered momentum calculations, impulse, and change in momentum (including ricochet).
scoreMessages.70: Very good! You understand the core concepts. Review vector nature of momentum in 2D changes.
scoreMessages.50: Fair. Focus on the impulse-momentum theorem (FΔt = Δp) and calculating momentum changes with direction.
scoreMessages.0: Start with the definition of momentum (p=mv) and impulse as change in momentum (J=Δp).
